research.title: IMPACT-Lab Overview
research.content: Our research focuses on Intelligent Modeling of Planetary Accretion, Convection, and Tectonics (IMPACT). We aim to uncover how initial conditions, mantle dynamics, and geochemical differentiation have shaped Earth and other planets. By leveraging cutting-edge AI/ML techniques together with interdisciplinary geophysical and geochemical models, we seek to answer fundamental questions about planetary formation, interior evolution, and long-term habitability.

sections.title: Geophysics
sections.content: We study Earth's deep structure using seismic data and numerical modeling to understand mantle dynamics and the origin of large-scale heterogeneities.

sections.title: Geochemistry
sections.content: Our geochemical research focuses on isotopic systems that preserve information about Earth's early history and ongoing processes.

sections.title: Igneous Petrology
sections.content: We investigate magmatic processes and the formation of igneous rocks to understand crustal evolution and mantle-crust interactions.

sections.title: Geochronology
sections.content: Using advanced dating techniques, we determine the timing of geological processes and construct temporal frameworks for Earth's evolution.

people.content: The IMPACT Group (Intelligent Modeling of Planetary Accretion, Convection, and Tectonics) in the Department of Geology & Geophysics at Texas A&M is part of the Research in Artificial Intelligence for Science and Engineering (RAISE) Initiative. We leverage AI/ML to build next-generation Earth and planetary simulations, tackling some of the biggest puzzles in Earth and other worlds. Our team values multidisciplinary collaboration, diversity, and a strong research spirit. If you‚Äôre interested in a PhD, postdoc, or undergraduate project, contact the PI at qyuan@tamu.edu

outreach.title: Outreach & Education
outreach.content: We are committed to sharing our research with the broader community through educational programs, public lectures, and collaborative initiatives. Work from the IMPACT Lab has been highlighted by premier outlets such as The New York Times, The Washington Post, Reuters, BBC News, CNN, TIME, and The Guardian‚Äîwith coverage in more than 1,300 publications worldwide‚Äîand featured on leading programs from National Geographic, NPR, and the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation. In recognition of this impact, the PI was invited to speak at Granada Hills Charter School, one of the largest high schools in the United States.

programs.title: Science Interview: Mar's Deep Secrets
programs.description: Dr. Yuan was recently featured in Science discussing groundbreaking new insights into Mars‚Äôs interior from InSight mission data, including the discovery of a solid inner core and large-scale heterogeneities. Together with colleagues worldwide, they discussed the knowns, unknowns, and conflicting interpretations of the Martian interior, while offering future perspectives on the Red Planet‚Äôs evolution, magnetic history, and long-term habitability.

programs.title: Nature Interview: Giant Impact Remnant
programs.description: Dr. Yuan‚Äôs study was spotlighted by Nature, which reported that giant mantle ‚Äòblobs‚Äô may be remnants of the Moon-forming impact with Theia 4.5 billion years ago. Experts noted that this research elevates a previously imaginative notion to a new level of seriousness, offering fresh perspectives on the connection between Earth‚Äôs deep interior and the Moon‚Äôs origin.

newsItems.title: New Research Published in Nature Geoscience
newsItems.excerpt: Our latest study on the giant impact origin of Large Low Shear Velocity Provinces has been published in Nature Geoscience, providing new insights into Earth's early bombardment history.
newsItems.content: Deep inside Earth, scientists have long puzzled over two giant mysterious regions above the planet‚Äôs core known as ‚Äúlarge low shear-wave velocity provinces‚Äù (LLSVPs), along with smaller patches called ‚Äúultra-low velocity zones‚Äù (ULVZs). These regions look very different from the rest of the mantle in seismic images, but their origin has remained unclear. Our new research suggests they may have formed from an ancient ‚Äúbasal magma ocean‚Äù at the bottom of Earth‚Äôs mantle, which was gradually mixed with material exsolved from the core. This process, which we call a ‚Äúbasal exsolution contaminated magma ocean‚Äù (BECMO), prevented the buildup of unrealistic iron-rich layers and instead produced mantle structures that match what seismologists observe today. Computer models show that solidified BECMO material could explain both the vast LLSVPs and the smaller ULVZs. The BECMO also carries distinctive chemical signals‚Äîsuch as silicon, tungsten, and helium isotopes‚Äîthat are often detected in volcanic rocks at ocean islands like Hawaii and Iceland. This means the same process may connect Earth‚Äôs deepest mantle to the volcanic activity we see at the surface, offering a unified explanation for some of the planet‚Äôs most enduring geochemical and geophysical mysteries.
keyFindings: Core exsolution suppresses the crystallization of ferropericlase, helping reconcile models of magma ocean solidification with seismic observations.
Geodynamic modeling shows these processes can produce mantle structures consistent with the anomalies we see in the lowermost mantle.
This deep reservoir carries isotopic signals (Si, W, He) from the core ‚Äî possibly explaining certain ocean island basalt sources.
The framework has implications for other planets with long-lived basal magma oceans and core‚Äìmantle interactions.

newsItems.title: Dr. Yuan started his new position as an assistant professor at Texas A&M
newsItems.content: Dr. Yuan completed his O.K. Earl Postdoc research at Caltech before joining the Department of Geology and Geophysics at Texas A&M University, where he established the IMPACT Lab‚ÄîIntelligent Modeling of Planetary Accretion, Convection, and Tectonics. He is also a core member of the Research in Artificial Intelligence for Science and Engineering (RAISE) Initiative at Texas A&M. The IMPACT Lab seeks to uncover how initial conditions, mantle dynamics, and geochemical differentiation shape Earth and other planets. By integrating cutting-edge AI/ML approaches with interdisciplinary geophysical and geochemical models, the lab aims to address fundamental questions about planetary formation, interior evolution, and long-term habitability.

newsItems.title: Invited presentation at University of Chicago
newsItems.excerpt: We are excited to announce a new research collaboration with xx University's .
newsItems.content: Dr. Yuan was honored to be invited to deliver a departmental colloquium at the University of Chicago. Among the distinguished audience members was Nobel laureate Jack Szostak, renowned for his pioneering contributions to our understanding of the origin of life. Before the lecture, Dr. Yuan had the rare opportunity to engage in an extended and thought-provoking discussion with Professor Szostak, exploring how his own findings on planetary dynamics and early Earth processes may provide new perspectives on prebiotic chemistry and the conditions that made life possible. This exchange underscored the interdisciplinary significance of Dr. Yuan‚Äôs work, bridging planetary science, geodynamics, and questions at the very heart of biology.
keyFindings: Interdisciplinary relevance ‚Äì Dr. Yuan‚Äôs research on planetary dynamics and early Earth processes offers new insights that connect geophysics with prebiotic chemistry, helping to frame conditions under which life could emerge.

newsItems.title: Featured in Science Magazine
newsItems.excerpt: Our research on Earth's early evolution will be featured in an upcoming National Geographic documentary about the formation of our planet.
newsItems.content: Dr. Qian Yuan was interviewed by Science magazine for the article, Ancient crystals point to a surprisingly early start for plate tectonics. In the piece, he offered expert commentary on how these new findings fit into the broader debate about the onset of plate tectonics and the thermal and chemical evolution of the early Earth. His perspective highlighted both the strengths of the new evidence and the challenges of interpreting ancient signals from Earth‚Äôs formative history.
keyFindings: While the zircon evidence is intriguing, it must be tested against geodynamic models to confirm whether Earth‚Äôs mantle could have sustained plate tectonics so early

newsItems.title: Powering Up: Our New NVIDIA GeForce RTX 5080 Has Arrived
newsItems.excerpt: Installation of a new high-precision mass spectrometer significantly expands our analytical capabilities for isotopic studies.
newsItems.content: The arrival of the NVIDIA GeForce RTX 5080 marks a major boost for our AI-powered geodynamics research. Its advanced GPU architecture dramatically accelerates neural network training, enabling us to process vast geophysical datasets and run complex mantle convection simulations more efficiently. This computational power allows us to integrate machine learning with high-resolution geodynamic models, uncovering patterns and predictions that were previously out of reach. Looking ahead, we plan to acquire 10 NVIDIA H100 GPUs in the coming months, which will further expand our ability to push the frontier of AI-driven Earth and planetary science.
keyFindings: Enhanced AI capabilities ‚Äì The new NVIDIA GeForce RTX 5080 accelerates neural network training and high-resolution geodynamic simulations, enabling faster and more advanced AI-powered research.

Scaling up resources ‚Äì The planned purchase of 10 NVIDIA H100 GPUs will significantly expand computational capacity, positioning the lab to tackle larger datasets and more complex planetary science problems.

positions.title: 2-3 PhD Student in Geophysics
positions.description: We are seeking a highly motivated PhD student to apply AI/ML techniques to computational modeling of mantle convection and the early evolution of Earth and other planets. The position will be based at Texas A&M University (TAMU), which hosts some of the best GPU computing resources in the nation, providing unparalleled opportunities for high-performance simulations and AI-driven research. In addition to outstanding computational infrastructure, TAMU offers a competitive stipend and benefits package, while the College Station area is known for its affordable cost of living and welcoming community. This unique combination of resources, support, and environment makes TAMU an ideal place to pursue cutting-edge research in planetary geodynamics and AI-powered Earth sciences.
requirements: Bachelor's degree in Geophysics, Physics, Mathematics, or related field
Strong background in mathematics and physics
Excellent written and verbal communication skills
benefits: Full funding including tuition and stipend

positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher in AI-driven geodynamics
positions.description: We invite applications for a postdoctoral position focused on AI-driven geodynamics. The postdoctoral scholar will work primarily with Prof. Qian Yuan to combine cutting-edge machine learning algorithms ‚Äì both data-driven and physics-based ‚Äì with mantle convection to understand planetary evolution and habitability.
requirements: PhD in Geodynamics, Earth and planetary sciences, Applied and computational mathematics, Physics, and Engineering
Experience with neural operators or PINNs (Physics-Informed Neural Networks)
Ability to work independently and collaboratively
benefits: Research funds for travel and equipment
